statement.tex: %text Find the distance of the point $P(6,5,9)$ from the plane determined by the points $A(3,-1,2)$, $B(5,2,4)$ and $C(-1,-1,6)$. %

step.context: %text If $A(3,-1,2)$, $B(5,2,4)$ and $C(-1,-1,6)$ are points on the plane and $\ora{AB}$ and $\ora{AC}$ are two vectors in this plane, what is $\ora{N}$, the{\bf normal} to the plane? %
%text If $\ora{N}=\vector{12}{16}{12}$ is the normal to the plane and $\ora{R}$ and $\ora{A}=\vector{3}{-1}{2}$ are points on the plane's surface, is the following valid? %
step.reason: %text Since $\ora{R}$ and $\ora{A}$ are along the plane and $\ora{N}$ is normal to the plane, $\ora{AR}\cdot \ora{N}$ must equal $0$. Therefore, % \begin{align} &\ora{AR}\cdot \ora{N}=0 \\ \implies &\left(\ora{R}-\ora{A}\right)\cdot \ora{N}=0 \\ \implies &\ora{R}\cdot \ora{N}=\ora{A}\cdot \ora{N} \\ \implies &\ora{R}\cdot \left(\vector{12}{16}{12}\right) \\ &\quad =\left(\vector{3}{-1}{2}\right)\cdot \left(\vector{12}{16}{12}\right) \\ \implies &\ora{R}\cdot \left(\vector{12}{16}{12}\right)=36-16+24 \\ \implies &\ora{R}\cdot \left(\vector{3}{4}{3}\right)-11=0 \end{align} \\ %text Since $\ora{R}$ is any point on the plane's surface $\ora{R}\cdot \left(\vector{3}{4}{3}\right)-11=0$ is effectively the vector equation of the plane. %

step.context: %text What is the distance between point $P(6,5,9)$ and the plane represented by the equation $\ora{R}\cdot \left(\vector{3}{4}{3}\right)-11=0$? %
step.reason: %text The plane $\ora{R}\cdot \left(\vector{3}{4}{3}\right)-11=0$ in cartesian form is $3x+4y+3z-11=0$. Distance from a point $P(6,5,9)$ to the plane is given by, % \begin{align} D&=\left\vert\dfrac{Ax+By+Cz+D}{\sqrt{A^2+B^2+C^2}}\right\vert \\ &=\left\vert\dfrac{3(6)+4(5)+3(9)-11}{\sqrt{3^2+4^2+3^2}}\right\vert \\ &=\left\vert\dfrac{18+20+27-11}{\sqrt{9+16+9}}\right\vert =\dfrac{54}{\sqrt{34}} \end{align}
